description: From Middle English prophecie, from Old French prophetie, from Latin prophētīa, from Ancient Greek προφητεία (prophēteía, “prophecy”), from προφήτης (prophḗtēs, “speaker of a god”), from πρό (pró, “before”) + φημί (phēmí, “I tell”). Displaced native Old English wītgung.

entries.meaning: A prediction, especially one made by a prophet or under divine inspiration.
examples: French writer Nostradamus made a prophecy in his book.

verbs.description: prophecy (third-person singular simple present prophecies, present participle prophecying, simple past and past participle prophecied)

examples: The manipulation of these tremendous beneficient energies helped the world so well that the vast majority of these prophecied catastrophies did not happen.
